awd_titl_txt: Electroweak reactions in Low-energy Nuclear Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
Many important reactions in nuclear physics cannot be measured with currently available experimental techniques. For example, the reaction probability of the process in which two protons fuse to form a Deuteron (a bound state of a neutron and a proton) is an important process in the sun, but cannot be measured experimentally; only theoretical calculations can provide this rate.  In the absence of guidance from experiment, it becomes important to quantify theoretical uncertainties. This project will address these issues for specific reactions. Analytical and numerical calculations will be used to determine reaction rates for astrophysically-relevant reaction rates, and new parametrizations of the internuclear interaction will be provided. Specifically, the PI and his students will use interactions that have been constructed using a theoretical tool known as effective field theory. This tool is an expansion that can be systematically improved by introducing, in a controlled manner, additional parameters to increase the accuracy of the interaction model. Numerical techniques will be used to determine the intrinsic error of this approach, parametrize the interaction, and calculate the reaction rates for selected processes. A quantification of resulting uncertainties will improve our understanding of the internuclear interaction.  This project will also provide an excellent training ground for graduate and undergraduate students and will contribute to a needed workforce in those technologies that rely on nuclear physics, which are relevant to security, energy and the health care sector. Graduate students will become familiarized with numerical methods that can be useful when working in industry.

This project follows a two-prong strategy that aims at improving our understanding of weak processes using effective field theory. Firstly, a number of weak processes in few-nucleon systems will be calculated within the unified framework of the so-called pionless effective field theory. Specifically, the well-measured decay half-life time of tritium will be treated and used to fix a parameter that within this framework is required for a high-accuracy of proton-proton fusion and weak proton capture on Helium-3. The second prong will focus on understanding the intrinsic error of Hamiltonians and associated electroweak currents generated with the so-called pionfull effective field theory. The PI will use novel numerical optimization/fitting techniques to establish an ordering scheme for the chiral potential and the associated electroweak currents that reflects the intrinsic error of the Hamiltonian order-by-order. Together with his collaborators, the PI will then use these results to calculate observables such as half-life times or total decay rates to new accuracy and with correct error estimates. The resulting interactions and currents will be made available to the nuclear theory community.

por.por_cntn:
This award ran over one year. During this period, we submitted 5 publications. Three of those have been accepted for publication while the remaining two are under review. Students were involved in the work for 4 of these publications and these received this way important training. In particular, students were involved in carrying out analytical and numerical calculations but also in the preparation of these publications/manuscripts.

The most important result of the research funded under this award was an uncertainty analysis of the so-called proton fusion process. In this reaction two protons fuse into a deuteron (a bound state of a neutron and a proton) while emitting a positron and a neutrino. This process is one of the most important nuclear reactions responsible for the sun's energy generation. The rate at which this process occurs in the sun cannot be measured in experiments because of its small size. We therefore have to rely on theoretical calculations to obtain this rate. One factor that limits the accuracy to which this observable can be calculate is the quality of the nuclear interaction that plays an important in the rate calculation. We focused in particular how much experimental data used to determine the nuclear interaction influences the proton-proton fusion rate. We found that this source of uncertainties is significantly higher than previously thought and that it limits the accuracy of calculations to 1%. We demonstrated therefore that a statistical analysis that takes uncertainties of input parameters is a key ingredient for calculations of nuclear observables.

Another important outcome of the work described above was the realization that additional uncertainties can hide in the computational framework used to obtain fusion rate observables. We identified such an error in an older calculation of the proton-proton fusion rate that arises because the quantum mechanical deuteron wave function was calculated and expressed in terms of a finite number of basis functions. While it was previously understood that an expansion in a finite number of basis functions can lead to errors, it was not appreciated that the calculation of an observable that involves a transition from an unbound to a bound state will display a larger error than naively expected. We have submitted a manuscript that identifies the source and the size of this uncertainty and provides ways to eliminate the uncertainty.

We studied also the application of a theoretical tool called the operator product expansion to strongly interacting many-body systems of low-energy particles with 2 spins. An example of such a system is an ultracold gas of neutrons. However, such systems are also studied in experiments with ultracold atoms. This tool has been successfully used before, however, only the first order in this expansion was worked. Specifically, it leads to equations that relate different observable quantities (such as the total energy, momentum distribution, etc.) through one additional measurable object (the so-called contact). In order to understand whether the uncertainty of the resulting equations can be reduced we carried out the operator product expansion to one order higher. We derived new relations that relate observable quantities to three other measurable system quantities.

Finally, we studied in the same spirit ways to increase the accuracy for the calculation of low-energy three-body systems interacting strongly through a short-range interaction. A so-called effective field theory expansion warrants that such systems can be described at first order in a low-energy with two parameters. One parameter from the two-body system and one from the three-body system. For three identical particles it has been understood that 2 additional parameters have to be included if the strength of the interaction can vary (one additional two-body parameter and one additional three-body parameter). We studied whether this inclusion changes when two identical and one different particle are studied and confirmed that the same conclusion still holds.
